author: TrashCat13
title: Works but Needs work
content: I buy my own HP ink and the printer does not let you use all the ink before it starts printing faded pages. According to the graphic in the app a quarter of the ink is wasted.  Also sometimes after manually adjusting the image and test printing it defaults back to original image not giving me a chance to tweak my adjustment or reprint it.  Having to login to check ink levels or make printer adjustments is inconvenient.  Pop up adds promoting the easy ink program is annoying too. No tutorial after major app updates.  My access to select my photos is buried below other folders so it does not show up on. my screen.  So you have to scroll down to see it.  At first I didn‚Äôt know there was other folders below what was on the screen so I could find my photos folder so I didn‚Äôt use the iPad app.  It was only after another app update that I noticed upon loading that it showed all the folders then resized to show only a few folders on my screen. so I tried scrolling down and found my photos folder. I‚Äôve had this printer for 5 years and when it breaks down I will be looking at other brands.

author: overpaidEngineer
title: All you can do wrong in a product in one
content:
If there was a case study on how bad a product can be, this should be one of the fine examples. Here are my findings for future scholars. 
1. Asks for subscriptions one too many times - this is a printer and a scanner, which blocks you from using anything other than their sub-par ink to print anything and you are asked to pay them money every month
2. Why do i need an account to scan my document? There is literally no logical reason to need an account for a scan job. 
3. Scan at 300DPI when my machine supports 1200DPI. Imagine you spent $100 on a high quality camera that can shoot at 48 megapixel, but the app, the only way to take the photo, delivers the product in 12 megapixel. Gameboy camera kit had a better resolution than this joke. 
4. Constantly disconnects after a scan job. Whoever designed the firmware clearly has no business in embedded software engineering if they can‚Äôt keep a connection alive. 
5. Apple human interface guideline is ignored in every chance. You guys clearly thought you had better UX than Apple guideline, which isn‚Äôt perfect, but light years better than this UX, designed when Germans were still flying overhead

author: Rotten terrifically awful
title: Too complicated
content: The process for setting up a printer so it can scan to email is RIDICULOUS. My previous HP printer model involved two steps to scan a document to a pdf that would go automatically to my email account. Now, with the new printer I have to use two devices, an app, set up an account, then follow several more steps to get the document from the app on my phone to my email account. If I don‚Äôt hear back from someone at HP explaining why this new process is necessary, let alone better, I will never ever buy an HP product EVER again and will do what I can to ensure others abide by the same. I am really unhappy with your product and it‚Äôs design.
